original: Dahlström, Gottfrid Otto Alexander, ingenjör, Västervik, f. 12/4/95 i Umeå landsförs. av köpm. Gottfrid D. o. Karin Sandström. G. 22 m. Ellen Persson. Barn: Ulf f. 39. — Tekn. sk. i Västerås 16, specielev i termodyna- mik o. förbränningsmotorer v. tekn. högsk. i Zürich 21. Komm:koll. stip. f. stud. av verkst:tekn. i Tyskl. 25, stud:- o. tj:res. t. Amerika, Engl, Ho-ll, Be’1’g., Ö’Siterr., Kina, Jap-an, Polen, Tjeckoslov., Schv^eiz, Ital., Ungern m. fl. länder 21-39. Prakt. h. ASEA i Västerås 11-16, verktygs-konstr. h. ASEA o. A-B Elektrover-ken i Västerås 16-19, verktygskonstr. o. flygmotorprov. h. A-B Thulinverken i Landskrona 19-20, bitr. drifts-ing. h. A-B Gunnebo Bruk i Varberg 20, maskinbefäl på 13.000 tons dieselmotorfartyget Formosa (i stud:- o. prakt :syfte) 21, verkst :ing. o. tekn. chef h. A-B Amerikanska Motorimporten i Malmö o. Sthlm 22-24, konstr., verkst :chef o. sederm. platschef h. A-B Avancemotor i Sthlm, konstr., verkst :ing. o. avd :chef h. A-B Bofors 30-41, konstr. h. Sv. Flygmotor A-B i Trollhättan 41-42, konstr:- o. verkst :chef h. A-B Slipmaterial-Naxos i Västervik sed. 43. Led. av Sv. uppfinn :fören. samt flera tekn. fören. o. komm., fartygsbesiktningsman S’ed. 45, batt:chef i luftv. 40-42. Uppfinn, t. omkr. 30 bevilj. sv. o. uti. patent å maskiner, motorfordon, förbränningsmotorer, flygplansutensilier, vapen, verktygsmaskiner o. verktyg m. m. Hobbies: segling, sport. FFrK4kl m sv, FMM m. sv. 40.
translated: Dahlström, Gottfrid Otto Alexander, engineer, Västervik, born on April 12th, 1895 in Umeå landsförs, to merchant Gottfrid D. and Karin Sandström. Married to Ellen Persson in 1922. They had a son named Ulf, born in 1939. He attended technical school in Västerås in 1916 and studied thermodynamics and combustion engines at the technical university in Zurich in 1921. He received a scholarship from the Swedish National Committee for Technical Research to study manufacturing technology in Germany in 1925 and then studied and worked in America, England, Holland, Belgium, Austria, China, Japan, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Switzerland, Italy, Hungary, and other countries from 1921 to 1939. He worked at ASEA in Västerås from 1911 to 1916, as a tool engineer at ASEA and A-B Elektroverken in Västerås from 1916 to 1919, as a tool engineer and aircraft engine tester at A-B Thulinverken in Landskrona from 1919 to 1920, as an assistant operating engineer at A-B Gunnebo Bruk in Varberg in 1920 and as an engineer on the 13,000 ton diesel engine ship, Formosa (for study and practical purposes) in 1921. He was an engineering and technical manager at A-B Amerikanska Motorimporten in Malmö and Stockholm from 1922 to 1924, as a design, engineering and production manager and later plant manager at A-B Avancemotor in Stockholm and as a design, engineering, and department manager at A-B Bofors from 1930 to 1941. He was also a designer at Swedish Flygmotor A-B in Trollhättan in 1941 to 1942 and a design and engineering manager at A-B Slipmaterial-Naxos in Västervik from 1943 onwards. He was a member of the Swedish invention association and several other technical societies and commissions, and was a ship inspector in 1945 and a battalion commander in the air defense from 1940 to 1942. He received about 30 Swedish and international patents for machines, motor vehicles, combustion engines, aircraft utensils, weapons, machine tools, and tools, among other things. His hobbies were sailing and sports. He was a member of FFrK4kl with medals in gold and FMM with medal in gold in 1940.

structured.description: Gottfrid Otto Alexander Dahlström was a Swedish engineer, born on April 12th, 1895 in Umeå landsförs, to merchant Gottfrid D. and Karin Sandström. He studied thermodynamics and combustion engines at the technical university in Zurich in 1921. He received a scholarship from the Swedish National Committee for Technical Research to study manufacturing technology in Germany in 1925 and then studied and worked in America, England, Holland, Belgium, Austria, China, Japan, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Switzerland, Italy, Hungary, and other countries from 1921 to 1939. He worked in various engineering roles in different organizations from 1911 to 1945. He was a member of the Swedish invention association and several other technical societies and commissions, and was a ship inspector in 1945 and a battalion commander in the air defense from 1940 to 1942. He received about 30 Swedish and international patents for machines, motor vehicles, combustion engines, aircraft utensils, weapons, machine tools, and tools, among other things. His hobbies were sailing and sports.
